item.title: About me
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I am an enthusiastic web designer and front-end developer. I work at Monki in Stockholm and I like to make stuff with HTML5, CSS and JavaScript.

About this site

This site was originally called Jamie Robertson Innit but was deemed to be too facetious. I remade everything in late 2013. The portfolio area slider below is built from scratch with some simple jQuery functions. It uses hardware accelerated css transforms and transitions, and on older browsers it falls back to using css positioning and transitions, and on even older browsers it uses regular jQuery animations. I also try to keep the slider in its last position by using a session cookie.

The icons in the navigation area are animated with css keyframe animations. If the browser doesn't support css keyframe animations, it will fallback to using the Spritely library to display animated javascript sprites.

If you like anything on my site please feel free to take a look at the source code or ask me a question about it.

Qualifications / Education:

Degree: The University of Edinburgh
Edinburgh College of Art
'Visual Communication' (B.A. Hons.)

My favourite resources

My most frequented resource is of course Stack Overflow due to its overwhelming wealth of information. I am also a keen follower of blogs like A List Apart, CSS Tricks, and most recently, the Codrops blog by Tympanus.

Typography

The headers on this site are set in Lato, which is available from Google web fonts. I use it in three weights and also make use of letter spacing and border-bottoms (not text-decoration underlines) to sex it up.

~ View my CV here ~

item.title: Contact me
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson

item.title: Welcome...
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: to my portfolio site. Here you can see my most recent project, find out about me, contact me and see my friends' work.

item.title: The Selfish Giant
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Personal project

A poster for a theatre production of Oscar Wilde's, 'The Selfish Giant'.

item.title: Complete-Compete
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: Graphic identity for a personal training and fitness company 'Complete-Compete'.

item.title: Thorntons
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Graphic Design / Branding

A personal project to design the front cover, back cover and first inside double page spread of a brochure for Thorntons legal firm which specializes in copyright protection.

item.title: The Diamond Kid
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A collaboration with creative writer, David Z. Wagner.

This illustration for the short story, 'The Diamond Kid' features in 'Garlic & Sapphires'- a book of collaborations of image and text.

item.title: Jackpot
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A collaboration with creative writer, David Z. Wagner.

This illustration was for his short story, ‘Jackpot’ about the personal effects of the financial crash and features in ‘Garlic & Sapphires’- a book of collaborations of image and text.

item.title: Shake Your Booty
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: My entry into a competition launched by Edinburgh's Owl & Lion gallery. The brief was to choose and illustrate a new collective noun, I chose, 'A Riot of Underwear'.

item.title: Foxhunt
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Illustration

This illustration was for a book review. The book, 'Nation at War' is about the conflicts and prejudices between country-folk and city-folk in Britain.

item.title: Environmentalist
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Competition Posters

Two A3 posters I made for Edinburgh College of Art (as part of a competition) to make people think about being more environmentally friendly. They were put up around the college which was cool.

item.title: Resistance
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: My entry into a D&AD competition, sponsored by Don't Panic media, to illustrate the concept of Resistance. The poster deals with themes of global communication, and its implications.

item.title: The Change
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A Promotional Piece

Two versions of New Year's Greetings cards to celebrate the start of 2010. The first version was sent out to prospective clients, friends and family. The second version was sent out to the 'Owl & Lion Gallery' in Edinburgh.

The quote is commonly attributed to Mahatma Gandhi, and is, "We need to be the change we wish to see in the world."

item.title: The Venue
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
In early April 2008 I was commissioned by 'Plum Developments' to do this mural for the new Venue Studios in Edinburgh (which was under construction).

The mural was about 2.5m x 16m. I had to kneel on a wheeley bin to reach to the top, and had a great time

item.title: The Jolly Milkman
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A simple and stylish website designed for the independent film production company, The Jolly Milkman.

I created an animated logo for the homepage using Adobe Flash. When the homepage loads, the animation below plays. (To view the animation click on the image below.)


[kml_flashembed publishmethod="static" fversion="8.0.0" movie="http://www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/the_jolly_milkman/jollyMilkman_header_v5.swf" width="450" height="150" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]

Responsive Design layout

The fully responsive layout was originally inspired by Less Framework. Both the layout, and the interactive elements resize, appear and disappear depending on the device used to view the site:

item.title: Snow Easy
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
In late 2011 / early 2012 I was commissioned to create an e-commerce site, www.snoweasy.eu for a new brand of snow shovels.

I tried to make the snow shovels look sexy and modern by presenting them in an abstract way on the homepage. The 'about' page features CAD illustrations that were mostly made in Adobe Illustrator and animated in Adobe Flash.

The site was built with HTML5, CSS3, Wordpress, jQuery and Flash.

[kml_flashembed publishmethod="static" fversion="8.0.0" movie="http://www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/files/snoweasy_v3.swf" width="620" height="583" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]

item.title: Gerard J.L.
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I was asked to design a portfolio website by the photographer, Gerard Jefferson-Lewis who wanted a site that was clean and functional. Visit the website here.

Many of the interactive elements on the site were built with Flash and ActionScript 3.0 and I made a simple backend with php.

item.title: Internship @ REALISE
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Between October and November I was lucky enough to be given a month long internship at 'Realise' digital agency in Edinburgh.

I worked on live projects for a variety of clients. I was creating client sites, doing competitor analysis concerning social networking, creating avatars and other icons, producing short augmented realities with After Effects and making Flash adverts.

The experience taught me a lot about working in a professional atmosphere, like the fast pace of production and edits.

I also learnt how to use flash tracking technologies like MediaMind (Eyeblaster) and DoubleClick, and about using Flash plugins such as greenSock, to speed up the creation of ads.

Here are some Flash adverts I created during the internship (click to play):


I also made a range of accountancy-themed avatars. The slideshow below shows a few of the ideas I tested out before arriving on the most suitable solution.

[kml_flashembed publishmethod="static" fversion="8.0.0" movie="http://www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/avatars_final.swf" width="352" height="352" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]

I was also asked to think of concepts for an aurasma. Aurasma is an augmented reality platform. When you see a print advert like the one below, you could hover your smart phone or tablet over the advert and once the device recognizes the image, it would play a short video commercial, possibly with a link at the end to find out more.

I used Adobe After Effects to create the short mock-up below, it was the third or fourth time I had used After Effects and really enjoyed the software, I hope I can use it much more in the future. (note: this work is draft quality, was done on spec and should be treated as a prototype).

[kml_flashembed publishmethod="static" fversion="8.0.0" movie="http://www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/hsbcWindyFinal.swf" width="580" height="480" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]

item.title: Experience @ EWM.
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
In December I did some work experience for a few days at 'EWM' digital agency in Edinburgh.

It was a brief internship in which I took an existing design on Photoshop and developed it to eventually become a Wordpress site that uses Paypal.

item.title: Velvet-Champagne
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A project to shake up a champagne brand

I designed a flash site for the company, Velvet Champagne. I wanted to make the site simple, satisfying to use and to communicate the different personalities of the two different types of champagne. The site was built in Flash CS5 and was lovingly hand-coded in ActionScript 3.0. There is fallback XHTML/CSS content will load if the user is viewing the site on a smartphone.

Visit the site.

See an example of the Facebook flash content.

item.title: Wax Drop
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: These flyers and posters were distributed around Edinburgh promoting a night at the nightclub, The Caves featuring the DJ, Wax Drop.

item.title: Absolutely Perfect
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: I was given a brief to design a visual identity and create concepts for a web site to establish and promote a new wedding planning company, Absolutely Perfect. Below is the logo featured on a business card.

item.title: Decaduckedence
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I was asked to create promotional material for a new catering company, called Hunter-Gatherer catering.

The long flyer below acted as an invite and a menu for a catering event. The ten birds featured were all stuffed into each other, starting with the smallest, before being roasted. I also made some flyers for the event's after-party, the 'Deckaduckedance'.

item.title: Ox Ad Soc
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
[kml_flashembed publishmethod="static" fversion="8.0.0" movie="http://www.jamierobertsoninteractive.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/oxadsocredo.swf" width="580" height="308" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]

Here is a short flash animation that I made to promote Oxford University's Advertising & Marketing Society. I used visual puns and bright colours to reflect the enthusiasm and lateral thinking of the society.

item.title: Hildas Ball 2011
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
A flash site designed for St. Hildas College

The brief was to design a site for their 50's styled end of year ball, called 'Rock Around The Clock'. The website is 50's themed, playful and easy to navigate.

The event was a big success with many people giving positive feedback from the website. The site has since been taken down but I have archived it here.

item.title: Degree Show
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Evo house - what a great studio to have worked from.

Goodbye Edinburgh College of Art :{ / Hello Big World :]

item.title: At One Training
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Visual Identity

I was commissioned to create an identity and temporary web site (archived here) for a new personal training centre in Crouch End, London

The site used Adobe Flash. It was made in inDesign and exported as a .swf.

item.title: Olivia Weinberg
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I designed this fully personalized Wordpress theme for an art journalist. I wanted to keep the design simple and elegant so as to keep the focus on the writing and images. There are quirky touches with the menu icons and footer background, which is supposed to look like the floor of an art gallery. Visit the site at www.oliviaweinberg.com.

Details from the site:

Holding page / Welcome page:

I also made an interactive holding page while I was working on the site. The initials OW were created with dots which changed colour when you rolled over them. It was so much fun that I was asked if it could be made into a welcome page. The original was made in Adobe Flash but then I made it again with jQuery. View the holding page here.

Potential Logotypes:

I experimented with many versions of the OW logotype, having fun with styles that evoked famous artists and art institutions.

item.title: Powder Byrne
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Working in partnership with Craftsman Websites I built a property letting website for Powder Byrne to showcase two new chalets in the skiing region of Laax, Switzerland.



Site 1: Providing information for Casa Prada




Site 2: Providing information for Casa Flumina


In addition to building the sites (both in German and English) I also created graphical illustrations of the properties, to sit within the menus, and floor plans.

I also created wireframes and ux architecture for the initial consultation.

item.title: Notting Hill Carnival App 2012
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
In the eight weeks leading up to the Notting Hill Carnival, Franky Athill and I designed and built our first native phone app- the 'Notting Hill Carnival App'.

Design:

The app consisted of a home screen with six interactive maps, one Twitter news feed and one static offline map. Each interactive map provided information on a different element of the carnival:

- transportation - the nearest tube stations and their current status
- the parade route - including the judging area
- first aid points
- food stalls
- sound systems - including a drop down list
- toilet facilities

   

Development:

The app was developed using the PhoneGap framework and used the Google Maps JavaScript API. This meant that the whole app could be written with HTML5 and CSS and all the programming could be done using JavaScript, jQuery and JSON. Using the PhoneGap framework meant that I could take advantage of the phone's native GPS functionality.

Accompanying Website:

We also created a dedicated website for the app, www.nottinghillcarnival.eu, which provides useful information about the carnival, interesting and relevant blog posts and directs users to the Google & Apple app stores.

Marketing / Promotion:

Stats:

Stats taken from one google play account and two app store accounts

Total number of unique Android user installs: 4,645

Total number of unique iPhone user installs: 14,995

Total number of unique user installs: 19,639

Awards:

item.title: BYT Revision App
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
From mid-September to November I worked from the client's office designing and developing a multiple-choice question app for Bright Young Things Tuition.

The app is available for all phones and tablet devices in the Apple and Android stores.

How was it made?

The app was developed with HTML5 & CSS and uses the PhoneGap framework.

- It also uses the jQuery Mobile, touch optimised framework.

- Icons and backgrounds were designed in Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator.

- All programming was done with JavaScript / jQuery.

- The app also uses JSON and the Mandrill API to send a certificate to the user.

item.title: BYT Lab
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I created this graphic identity for a new business consultancy, BYTlab.com.

The consultancy was created by the partnership between 'Bright Young Things Tuition' and 'Group Olivo' consultancy.
To speed up the development process I adapted a Wordpress theme to my needs. I designed a range of identities for the business before settling on a lower-case b inspired by isometric grids and molecular diagrams.

item.title: BYT Facebook Tab App
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: A Facebook 'tab app' made for Bright Young Things Tuition. Hosted on the cloud by heroku, deployed with Git and using the Mandrill add-on.

item.title: Artist's Online Portfolio
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: This website was built for an artist who wanted a very organized portfolio site that was easy to update. I decided to use Wordpress as a CMS but heavily modified it, changing the admin interface by exploiting the featured image functionality so that it was image-centric, as opposed to the default Wordpress interface, which focusses on text. The result is an admin area perfectly suited to this particular role.

item.title: Partners in therapy website
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded: I finished this one page scrolling site and branding for a partnership of professional therapists in late 2013. The site is responsive and uses Modernizr to check for browser compatibility.

item.title: Notting Hill Carnival App 2013
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Version 2.0

Just like the first version for 2012, the objective of the app was to provide a custom map for the Notting Hill Carnival that showed the location of the soundsystems and other important points of interest. It was a collaborative project with Franky and Adlai and used PhoneGap.

Before we started developing the second version of the app we identified areas that we wanted to improve and new features we wanted to include:

Locally served map

The Notting Hill Carnival attracts around 1.5 million festival goers. Due to the high density of crowds, mobile phone signal is patchy at best and between 5pm and 7pm is almost non existent. This means that we could not rely on 3g signal to load the Google maps api.
Our solution to this problem was to design our own map in Adobe Illustrator and serve it locally.

We also wanted the user to be able to see where they were on the map. To do this we used Phonegap's geolocation feature combined with data we already know about the area and translate it into absolute CSS positioning relative to the full width and height of the map.

Faster touch events

I decided to use Zepto instead of jQuery. Zepto is a minimalist JavaScript library for modern browsers. This makes it highly suitable for use with mobile browsers, and thus perfect for PhoneGap. Another great feature of Zepto is its touch events that respond faster than standard jQuery click events (used for version 1).

Redesigned user experience

I wanted to make the interface more minimal as possible in order to shift the focus to the map.

item.title: Photographer's Online Portfolio
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I made this simple, clean website for a friend of mine who is a great photographer.
The overall concept behind the design is to make the layout as easy as possible to scroll. If the site is viewed from a mobile device or on a portrait format tablet, the images will adjust from a horizontal to a vertical alignment. At a vertical alignment the navigation is hidden to make more space for the photographs.
The site is touch optimised and the sliding panel uses CSS hardware acceleration. I also decided to use Mika Tuupola's jQuery lazyload plugin to give the impression of faster page loading speeds and thus provide a better user experience.

item.title: Monkified
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
Jamie ♡ Monki

From April 2013 until January 2014 I was employed to do Graphic Design and Final Art for Monki in Stockholm. The position I filled was free because of pappaledighet. Monki is a storytelling fashion retail brand for young women. My role at Monki included:
  • - Doing artwork for their seasonal campaigns, and promotional material
  • - Re-designing the labels - producing conceptual and technical artworks
  • - Designing and doing front-end development work for an internal website
  • - Doing front-end development work for their MonkiSaga campaign
If you would like to see a selection of the work I produced while at Monki please contact me on this page.

item.title: Getty Images API
item.dc:creator: mrjrobertson
item.content:encoded:
I was commissioned by Dot Web Design to work with Getty Images' API, called Connect. My brief was to design and develop an image search interface for an ecommerce site that sells printed canvas wall panels.

The brief was to make it work like this:
1. The user types in a word or phrase and relevant images appear,
2. The user chooses their favourite image and selects the right size,
3. The user adds the item to the shopping cart and repeats the process until satisfied, then goes to the checkout.

How it was made

I used jQuery for DOM manipulation and to store the input values. The data was then sent using JSON to a pHp script that used the Zend Framework to handle the api call.

Working with the API was challenging because at the time it was quite new and so had a small user community. However Getty does provide quite good documentation and now has a good forum on its api site.

Http Requests with the Zend Framework (v2)

I started by trying to everything in jQuery and JSON, but eventually got stuck when it came to making the http post requests.

In order to make http post requests successfully without falling foul of the same-origin security issues, Getty recommends using the Zend framework. This was my first time using the Zend framework and initially found it quite intimidating due to its overwhelming size. After a few headaches I finally decided that the best approach was to use just the Zend components that I needed.

If anyone is reading this and is having similar problems, please drop me an email and I will send the code I used. Hopefully it will save you a lot of time.
